[[Secularism]] | homepage = [http://www.6april.org/ 6april.org] | tax_exempt = | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''April 6 Youth Movement''' ''({{lang-ar|Ø­Ø±ÙØ© Ø´Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ 6 Ø£Ø¨Ø±ÙÙ}})'' is an [[Egypt]]ian [[Facebook]] group started in Spring 2008 to support the workers in [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]], an industrial town, who were planning to strike on April 6.{{Cite journal|url=http://www.wired.com/techbiz/startups/magazine/16-11/ff_facebookegypt |title= Cairo Activists Use Facebook to Rattle Regime |date=October 20, 2008 |first=David |last=Wolman |journal=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |publisher=[[CondÃ© Nast Publications]] |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}{{cite news|title=Parliament is burning, and the watching crowd is laughing |first=Hamida |last=Ghafour |date=August 25, 2008 |work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |publisher=[[Martin Newland]]|url=http://www.thenational.ae/article/20080825/OPINION/235828560/1080&template=opinion |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}{{cite news|url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=15325 |work=[[Daily News Egypt]] |title=Protestors say Agrium plant is like Nazi gas chambers |first=Abdel-Rahman |last=Hussein |date=July 27, 2008 |publisher=Egyptian Media Services |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}{{Cite news|work=Daily News Egypt |title=April 6 youth detainees still in custody despite release order|publisher=Egyptian Media Services |first=Sarah |last=Carr |date=July 30, 2008 |url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=15407 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}{{cite news|url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=16577 |work=Daily News Egypt|title=Emaar accused of culpability in Duweiqa rockslide|publisher=Egyptian Media Services |first=Abdel-Rahman |last=Hussein |date=September 18, 2008 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}}{{cite news|title=In Focus: The Dilemma of Egyptâs Liberals |first=Khalil |last=Al-Anani |date=September 2, 2008|publisher=Egyptian Media Services |work=Daily News Egypt|url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=16173 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}} Activists called on participants to wear black and stay home on the day of the strike. Bloggers and citizen journalists used [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], [[Flickr]], blogs and other new media tools to report on the strike, alert their networks about police activity, organize legal protection and draw attention to their efforts.{{cite journal|url=http://www.arabmediasociety.com/?article=692|work=Arab Media & Society|title=Core to Commonplace: The evolution of Egypt's blogosphere|publisher=American University of Cairo |first=Courtney |last=Radsch |date=Fall 2008 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' has identified the movement as the political Facebook group in Egypt with the most dynamic debates.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/25/magazine/25bloggers-t.html |title=Revolution, Facebook-Style |first=Samantha M |last=Shapiro |work=The New York Times |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |date=January 22, 2009 |accessdate=February 15, 2008}} {{As of|January 2009}}, it had 70,000 predominantly young and educated members, most of whom had not been politically active before; their core concerns include [[free speech]], [[nepotism]] in government and the country's stagnant economy. Their discussion forum on Facebook features intense and heated discussions, and is constantly updated with new postings. The April 6 movement is using the same [[raised fist]] symbol as the [[Otpor!]] movement from [[Serbia]], that helped bring down the regime of [[Slobodan MiloÅ¡eviÄ]] and whose nonviolent tactics were later used in [[Ukraine]] and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. ==Founders== * [[Ahmed Maher (youth leader)|Ahmed Maher]][http://www.aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3&id=24109 Asharq Al-Awsat] was a participant in the anti-[[Mubarak]] demonstrations in [[Egypt]] in 2011.Esam Al-Amin, [http://www.counterpunch.com/amin02042011.html From Counter-Attack to Departure Day], Counterpunch, 4 February 2011David Wolman, [http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/leading-egyptian-facebook-activist-arrested-friends-say/ Did Egypt Detain a Top Facebook Activist?] , Wired, 2 February 2011 * [[Waleed Rashed]], born November 15, 1983 in El Sharkia, Egypt) is one of the co-founders of the April 6 Youth Movement and a participant in the anti-Mubarak demonstrations in Egypt in 2011 Rashed is a banker. Rashed has traveled to Algeria, USA , Greece , United Arab Emirates, Turkey, Bahrain, Qatar and Lebanon and has been arrested several times by the Egyptian police for his political activism. Since 2005 he was a member of the Kafaya movement, also known as the [[Egyptian_Movement_for_Change|Egyptian Movement for Change]]. From 2009-2010, he worked in Qatar, where he was the coordinator of the National Association of Change and organized the Egyptians in the area to support the change of regime * [[Asmaa Mahfouz]] posted a video blog that went [[Viral video|viral]].[http://boingboing.net/2011/02/02/egypt-the-viral-vlog.html Egypt: The viral vlog of Asmaa Mahfouz] She urged the Egyptian people to join her in a protest on January 25, in [[Tahrir Square]] to bring down Mubarakâs regime[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02iht-letter02.html?_r=1 The New York Times] and urged people not to be afraid.[http://www.thecanadiancharger.com/page.php?id=5&a=774 The Canadian Charger] ==Public activism and arrests== Aside from discussing the state of the nation online, members of the group have organized public rallies to free imprisoned journalists and engaged in protests concerning the [[2008â2009 IsraelâGaza conflict]]. In its official pronouncements, the group stresses that it is not a [[political party]]. Ahmed Maher, one of the founders of the group, was arrested by the Egyptian authorities in May 2008 in an attempt to shut it down.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2008/05/17/ST2008051702711.html|title=Fledgling Rebellion on Facebook Is Struck Down by Force in Egypt|author=Ellen Knickmeyer|publisher=Washington Post|date=2008-05-18|accessdate=2009-02-16}} In July 2008, Maher was again arrested, along with 14 other members of the group, and charged with "incitement against the regime". He also claimed that Egyptian state security officers threatened to rape him in custody.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2008/0730/p04s04-wome.html|title=Egypt detains Facebook activists â again|author=Liam Stack|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|date=2008-07-30|accessdate=2009-02-16}} On April 6, 2009 the group was subjected to attacks, suspected to have been orchestrated by the Egyptian government. Several websites supporting the group were hacked simultaneously, and protests in Cairo were confronted by plain clothed Egyptian policemen and numerous arrests.[http://egyptianchronicles.blogspot.com/ Egyptian Chronicles]. Egyptianchronicles.blogspot.com. Retrieved on 2011-03-12. On January 29, 2011 a [[WikiLeaks]] document was revealed which showed that the United States considered the movement to be "outside (the) mainstream of opposition politicians and activists" and described the goals of the movement for democracy as "unrealistic" yet still supported it in various ways, including pressing "the MFA for the release of April 6 activists".[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8289698/Egypt-protests-secret-US-document-discloses-support-for-protesters.html Egypt protests: secret US document discloses support for protesters]. Telegraph (2011-01-28). Retrieved on 2011-03-12. On January 31, 2011 the movement promoted participation of at least a million in a march on Tuesday, February 1, 2011.anon., [http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html "Egypt protesters increase pressure: Opposition movement calls for "march of millions"] on Tuesday in a bid to topple president Hosni Mubarak." (Jan. 31, 2011) On Feb 03, 2011 the [[Hisham Mubarak Law Center]] which was providing meeting space for the April 6 Youth Movement as well as providing medical and legal aid to the protesters was raided by security forces who arrested Amal Sharaf and other members of April 6.[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/4d590d711a.html "Egypt: Investigate Arrests of Activists, Journalists"] ''UN HCR'', 9 Feb 2011 ==See also== {{Portal box|Egypt|Human rights}} * [[Hazem Salah Abu Ismail]] * [[Saad Eddin Ibrahim]] * [[Waleed Rashed]] * [[Ayman Nour]] â an Egyptian opposition leader, head of the [[Tomorrow Party]] * [[Civil resistance]] * [[Nonviolent resistance]] * [[Hosni Mubarak]] * [[Kefaya]] * [[National Association for Change]] * [[Hisham Mubarak Law Center]] * [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite news | first = David D. | last = Kirkpatrick | coauthors = David E. Sanger | title = A Tunisian-Egyptian link that shook Arab history | date = February 13, 2011 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/14/world/middleeast/14egypt-tunisia-protests.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2011-02-27}} * {{cite news | first = David | last = Wolman | title = The techie dissidents who showed Egyptians how to organize online | date = February 13, 2011 | url = http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2011/02/the-techie-dissidents-who-showed-egyptians-how-to-organize-online/70734/ | work = The Atlantic | accessdate = 2011-02-27}} ==External links== * [http://6april.org/ 6 April Youth Movement] ''official site'' (Arabic) * [http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=9973986703 April 6 Movement Facebook group page] * [http://6aprilmove.blogspot.com/ April 6 Movement Blog Ø­Ø±ÙØ© 6 Ø§Ø¨Ø±ÙÙ] * [http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/peopleandpower/2011/02/201128145549829916.html Documentary] on April 6 Movement's involvement with the Egyptian Revolution * [http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/english-free-tags/6-april-protest-movement Collected news coverage] at ''[[Al-Masry Al-Youm]]'' * hashtag: #6April {{2010â2011 Middle East and North Africa protests}} {{Egypt topics}} [[Category:2011 Egyptian revolution|Egypt]] [[Category:2011 in Egypt]] [[Category:2011 riots]] [[Category:Politics of Egypt]] [[Category:Protests in Egypt]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Egypt]] [[Category:2008 establishments]] [[Category:Nonviolence organizations]] [[ar:Ø­Ø±ÙØ© Ø´Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ 6 Ø£Ø¨Ø±ÙÙ]] [[az:â6 aprelâ HÉrÉkatÄ±]] [[de:Jugendbewegung des 6.
